docs.snippet: About one-third of major league pitchers have had the procedure to reconstruct the ulnar collateral ligaments in their elbows, and more and more are back for a second one....
docs.lead_paragraph: About one-third of major league pitchers have had the procedure to reconstruct the ulnar collateral ligaments in their elbows, and more and more are back for a second one.
docs.abstract: Tyler Kepner On Baseball column notes that about one-third of major league pitchers have undergone Tommy John surgery to reconstruct ligaments in their elbows, with a growing number doing it more than once; holds that while procedure revives many careers, some pitchers struggle to recapture what they once had.

headline.main: A Growing Fraternity: Tommy John Patients
headline.print_headline: A Fast-Growing Fraternity in the Game: Tommy John Patients

docs.snippet: When Jacoby Ellsbury, out with a calf injury, left Boston for the Yankees, it opened the door for Jackie Bradley Jr. to take over in center field....
docs.lead_paragraph: When Jacoby Ellsbury, out with a calf injury, left Boston for the Yankees, it opened the door for Jackie Bradley Jr. to take over in center field.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox remain confident about center field future for Jackie Bradley Jr, who rose to position after Jacoby Ellsbury left for the New York Yankees; Bradley has struggled so far during spring training games.

headline.main: Ellsbury’s Replacement Is Struggling, but He’s Playing
headline.print_headline: Ellsbury’s Replacement Struggles, but He’s Playing

docs.snippet: Noah Syndergaard, Rafael Montero and Cory Mazzoni were sent to Las Vegas, the Mets’ Class AAA minor league affiliate....
docs.lead_paragraph: Noah Syndergaard, Rafael Montero and Cory Mazzoni were sent to Las Vegas, the Mets’ Class AAA minor league affiliate.
docs.abstract: New York Mets, flush with pitchers, send top prospect Noah Syndergaard back to the minor leagues, where he will start the 2014 season at Class AAA Las Vegas; Syndergaard will likely be called back up by midseason if he performs well.

headline.main: Mets Send Syndergaard, a Top Prospect, to the Minors
headline.print_headline: Mets Send Syndergaard, a Top Prospect, to the Minors

docs.snippet: LANDAU--Gerald Leonard, 95. Loving husband of 67 years of Miriam Landau, proud father of Jonathan Landau, and wife Barbara, David Landau, and wife Gretchen, loving grandfather to Kate Downey Landau, and Charles Downey Landau, and Jennifer Yankelio...
docs.lead_paragraph: LANDAU--Gerald Leonard, 95. Loving husband of 67 years of Miriam Landau, proud father of Jonathan Landau, and wife Barbara, David Landau, and wife Gretchen, loving grandfather to Kate Downey Landau, and Charles Downey Landau, and Jennifer Yankeliovich, and, in the last four months of his life, great- grandfather to Gerald Yankeliovich Landau. The second of four children, he was predeceased by his older brother Herb, younger brother Martin, and younger sister Bernice. Born in 1919, in his early years he developed a passionate interest in jazz and baseball. Among his many heroes were Louis Armstrong, whose music he was still listening to just last month, and Willie Mays. During World War II he served as a paratrooper, and made 22 jumps during the war. After the war, he attended Brooklyn College and became a school teacher and historian until he was blacklisted by the New York City school system in 1952 for his political activities. In 1959, he began a second career when he joined the new Acoustic Research company and went on to be become its Vice President before retiring. Gerald was a lifetime student of language and always spoke with precision and clarity. He was an intellectual who followed the news and history of the world around him with great care and understanding. He had a talent for inventing children's stories and his tales about "Bruin the Bear" are considered classics, especially by his grandchildren. A charming and handsome man, with a twinkle in his eyes, a relaxed and friendly manner, he was always a natural, interesting, and witty conversationalist. Over the course of his 95 years, the most important thing to him was the love he shared with Miriam, Jonathan, Barbara, David, Gretchen, Kate, Charles, and young Gerald--his family, who loved him with all their heart. Plans for a memorial will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made to Doctors Without Borders.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, GERALD L.
